arm_group.description: Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) 2mA for 20 minutes over the primary motor cortex (M1) in the affected hemisphere followed by robotic arm therapy for 60 minutes, 3x per week for 12 weeks

Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation sham condition (0 mA) for 20 minutes over the primary motor cortex (M1) in the affected hemisphere followed by robotic arm therapy for 60 minutes, 3x per week for 12 weeks

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to evaluate if multiple therapy sessions of Transcranial Direct
      Current Stimulation (tDCS non-invasive brain stimulation) combined with robotic arm therapy
      lead to a greater functional recovery in upper limb mobility after stroke than that provided
      by robotic arm therapy alone.

clinical_study.brief_title: Robots Paired With tDCS in Stroke Recovery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  18 years of age or older

          -  First single focal unilateral lesion with diagnosis verified by brain imaging, which
             occurred at least 6 months prior

          -  Cognitive function sufficient enough to understand experiments and follow
             instructions

          -  Fugl-Meyer assessment of 7 to 58 out of 66 (neither hemiplegic nor fully recovered
             motor function in the muscles of the shoulder, elbow, and wrist)

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Botox treatment within 6 weeks of enrollment

          -  Fixed contraction of the affected limb

          -  Complete flaccid paralysis of the affected limb

          -  History of hemorrhagic stroke

          -  Ongoing use of CNS active medications

          -  Ongoing use of psychoactive medications

          -  Presence of additional potential tDCS/TMS risk factors including damaged skin at site
             of stimulation, presence of a magnetically/mechanically active implant, metal in the
             head, family history of epilepsy, and personal history of seizures

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation Paired With Robotic Arm Therapy on Recovery of Upper Extremity Motor Function in Stroke Patients

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Upper Extremity Fugl Meyer Assessment
primary_outcome.time_frame: 12 weeks (immediately following the intervention) and 36 weeks (6 months after the intervention)

reference.citation: Edwards DJ, Krebs HI, Rykman A, Zipse J, Thickbroom GW, Mastaglia FL, Pascual-Leone A, Volpe BT. Raised corticomotor excitability of M1 forearm area following anodal tDCS is sustained during robotic wrist therapy in chronic stroke. Restor Neurol Neurosci. 2009;27(3):199-207.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Kinematic Data of upper extremity mobility as measure by Interactive Motion Technologies planar (shoulder/elbow) robot and wrist (wrist flexion/extension and pronation/supination) robots during therapy and evaluations
secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Kinematic Data
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 12 weeks (immediately following the intervention) and 36 weeks (6 months after the intervention)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in WOLF motor function test
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 12 weeks (immediately following the intervention) and 36 weeks (6 months after the intervention)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Motor Power Manual Muscle Test
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 12 weeks (immediately following the intervention) and 36 weeks (6 months after the intervention)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in NIH stroke scale
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 12 weeks (immediately following the intervention) and 36 weeks (6 months after the intervention)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Stroke Impact Scale (SIS)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 12 weeks (immediately following the intervention) and 36 weeks (6 months after the intervention)

clinical_study.source: North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System

lead_sponsor.agency: North Shore Long Island Jewish Health System

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Outcomes Assessor), Primary Purpose: Treatment
